parts: Name this Tom Wolfe novel that follows Ken Kesey and the Merry Pranksters and their cross-country adventures as well as their experiences experimenting with LSD.
The Electric Kool-Aid Acid Test is one of the most famous works of this literary style, unconventional for its subjective perspective and writers’ immersion in their story matter.
Wolfe also wrote this controversial 1989 essay featured in Harper’s Magazine in which he criticized contemporary American novels for retreating from realism.
Name this archangel who in that book travels with Tobias to help him marry a demon-filled woman and to heal his father’s blindness with a fish’s gallbladder after birds have pooped on them.

Two other books included in the Catholic deuterocanon but rejected by Protestants are titled after this group of Jewish rebels from the second century B.C.E. The second of those books recounts how Judas restored the temple, an event commemorated during Hanukkah.

Other portions of the deuterocanon include a passage in the book of Daniel about this type of animal, which is revered by the Babylonians but bursts open and dies after Daniel feeds it a cake made from pitch, fat, and hair.

The prize was awarded to Dubochet, Frank, and Henderson for their pioneering work in the cryo-electron form of this field that probes small resolution ranges. Other types of this field include “scanning electron” and “optical.”

Dubochet’s contribution to the field involved performing this process on water. In general, this process transforms a substance into a non-crystalline amorphous glass, so that if water is cooled rapidly enough, biomolecules will not be damaged by crystal formation.

Cryo-electron microscopy made possible the three-dimensional surface mapping of this virus, which led to the discovery of an E glycoprotein distinct from other flaviviruses, a discovery which may help prevent outbreaks of this virus like the one that began in 2015 in Brazil.

answers: Boyd v. United States [or Boyd v. U.S.] <Jin>
parts: Name this 1961 U.S. Supreme Court case in which a woman from Cleveland claimed she could not be prosecuted for the seizure of pornographic material found in her house during a search for gambling paraphernalia.
Mapp v. Ohio established the exclusionary rule, which prevents evidence obtained without a warrant from being used in court. This legal metaphor is used to describe such illegally-obtained evidence.

The decision in Mapp v. Ohio was based on this earlier 1886 U.S. Supreme Court case in which a government search of a company’s invoice papers was referred to by the court as “unreasonable search and seizure.”

answers: golden ratio [or divine proportion or medial section; prompt on an approximation like 1.618]
parts: Identify this constant, symbolized lowercase phi, which is equal to its reciprocal plus one.

Because it is the root of the polynomial x2-x-1 [x-squared minus x minus one], the golden ratio is this type of number, which differs from transcendental numbers like pi in that it can be expressed as the root of a polynomial with non-zero, rational coefficients.

The golden ratio is also the limit of the ratio of consecutive numbers in a sequence named for the author of this work. That author, Fibonacci, did not mention the golden ratio in this work, instead spending most of the time rocking the Western world with the Hindu–Arabic numeral system and making up stories about rabbits.

answers: The Hundred Days [anti-prompt on War of the Seventh Coalition]
parts: Name this man who served as British prime minister twice as a Tory after the end of the Napoleonic Wars and oversaw the passage of the Catholic Relief Act of 1829 and the Reform Act of 1832.

Arthur Wellesley commanded the allied army, along with a Prussian army under Blücher, at the Battle of Waterloo during this period between Napoleon’s return from exile and the second restoration of Louis XVIII [“the eighteenth”].

During the Hundred Days, this meeting was occurring simultaneously. Its main objective was to secure a long term peace in Europe following Napoleon’s surrender in May 1814, and it was chaired by Austrian statesman Klemens von Metternich.

answers: RuBisCO [or ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate carboxylase oxygenase, but not if they’re trying to sound smart and end up messing up part of it]
parts: Name this cycle in which ribulose bisphosphate catches carbon dioxide and makes sugar for plants.

This enzyme catalyzes the first major step of carbon fixation in the Calvin cycle. It uses ATP and NADPH to break six-carbon molecules into two equal parts, and it is the most abundant protein on Earth.

To ensure that RuBisCO is not wastefully fixing oxygen instead of carbon dioxide, this pathway is utilized by some plants to bypass the photorespiration pathway. It involves binding PEP with CO2 to produce a compound with its namesake number of carbons.
This Romanian-born American Jew wrote the memoir Night to describe his experiences in Auschwitz and Buchenwald. He also wrote “The Jews of Silence.”
This girl lived in an attic with her family for two years while hiding from the Nazi occupation of the Netherlands, which she recounts in her work The Diary of a Young Girl.

This is Anne Frank’s older sister. She apparently kept a diary of her own that has never been found, and both her and Anne died of typhus a few months after being transferred out of Auschwitz to a different camp.

answers: burned at the stake [or obvious equivalents] <Halza>
parts: Name this Bohemian priest, who was an advocate of realism in the Catholic Church and was a strong proponent of John Wycliffe, whose writings were first banned by Pope Innocent VII [“the seventh”].

Jan Hus [YAWN HOOSE], startled by the educational disparity of country priests in Bohemia, translated many religious texts into this language, his native tongue. Jan Hus completed much of his work before leaving university in Prague.

Having been found guilty of heresy by the Catholic Church, Jan Hus was put to death in this manner. Joan of Arc was also notably put to death in this fashion due to a conviction of heresy by repeated cross-dressing.
Name this phenomenon that occurs when the atmospheric field strength exceeds about three million volts per meter.
Lightning consists of the partially-ionized form of this state of matter which may be the most abundant state in the Universe because of its presence in stars.
Lightning is initiated by this effect when water and ice droplets interact with friction. This effect’s namesake series pairs amber with wool and glass with silk.

answers: The Carnival of the Animals [or Le carnaval des animaux]
Fossils [or Fossiles; prompt on the twelfth movement]
parts: Name this zoological fantasy by Camille Saint-Saëns [ca-MEE san-SAW] that includes such movements as “Characters with Long Ears” and “The Swan.”

This movement of The Carnival of the Animals quotes the French “Twinkle Twinkle Little Star” and Rossini’s “Una voce [VOH-chay] poco fa.” The xylophone in this movement mimics another composition by Saint-Saëns, Danse Macabre.

The ninth movement, The Cuckoo in the Depths of the Woods, is scored for these two instruments. One repeats the two-note ostinato C-A-flat to mimic the call of the cuckoo, while a pair of the other instrument supplies large, soft chords.
Name this man who loved to stretch people or cut off their feet to make them fit his beds.
In the underworld, this son of Elara and Zeus was stretched out over nine acres and had his liver eaten by two vultures. Hera had him try to rape Leto in revenge for Zeus’ infidelity.
Like Tityus, this titan, who brought fire to mankind, was chained to a rock and had his liver eaten until he was freed by Hercules.
Name this double portrait by Hans Holbein the Younger in which Jean de Dinteville and Georges de Selve stand next to shelves of various scientific, musical, and religious items.

This object appears distorted at the bottom of The Ambassadors, rendered in anamorphic perspective. This object’s inclusion in the painting may be for the thematic representation of mortality and death.
Another reminder of mortality in the painting is this object, which appears in the upper left on the wall and is partially obscured by the green curtain covering the rest of the upper background.

Hannibal, noted for his use of war elephants, was defeated at this battle by Scipio Africanus, who brilliantly defeated the formidable elephants by allowing them to charge past his ranks and remove them from battle.

These small animals were used extensively in World War I to communicate between army divisions. One of these animals, a blue check hen named Cher Ami, delivered a message saving the “Lost Battalion” despite being shot in the wing.

The Russian military trained dogs strapped with explosives to run under enemy tanks in this war. Although their success is uncertain, twelve German tanks were disabled by dog-chartered explosives at the Battle of Kursk in this war.

answers: being buried alive in the temple vault <McMaken>
parts: Name this Italian opera by Giuseppe Verdi in which Amneris vies with the title princess for the love of Radamès.
Aida and her father Amonasro are from this country, having been captured and enslaved by the Egyptians.
For Radamès’ treason, he is sentenced to die in this manner. He soon finds that Aida has also sneaked her way to die in this manner as well.

This coastal port city is the most populated city in Nigeria and was the capital prior to the transition to Abuja in 1991. Separated into two portions, the “Island” and the “Mainland,” this city gets its name from the Portuguese word for “lakes.”

Maiduguri, the capital of Borno State, is situated near the Firki swamps of this natural feature. The terrorist group Boko Haram is prolific in the undeveloped northeastern Nigerian landscape around this receding endorheic lake.

This capital and largest city of Rivers State is Nigeria’s primary exporter of petroleum. Located in the Niger Delta, this southeastern city is located on the Bonny River prior to its drainage in the Gulf of Guinea.

answers: Dr. Yu Tsun [accept either underlined portion]
Jorge Francisco Isidoro Luis Borges Acevedo <Jin>
parts: For 10 points, name this essay that critiques the work of an English philosopher, An Essay towards a Real Character and a Philosophical Language, which proposes a system for a universal language.

The same author who wrote “The Analytical Language of John Wilkins” also wrote about this character, a German spy who conveys the reveals the location of an artillery park by murdering a man who shared the location’s name.

This Argentine author wrote both “The Analytical Language of John Wilkins” and The Garden of Forking Paths, in which Dr. Yu Tsun appears. He is also known for other works such as “The Aleph” and “The Library of Babel.”
This former White House Press Secretary was often satirized on Saturday Night Live by an emphatic Melissa McCarthy and was noted for his habit of chewing and swallowing large quantities of gum.
Name this former member of President Trump’s Cabinet, who resigned from his post as Secretary of Health and Human Services due to inappropriate use of government aircrafts and charters.
This former White House Director of Communications and confidante to President Trump resigned suddenly on March 1st, 2018. She succeeded Anthony Scaramucci in her post.

answers: Fear and Trembling [or Frygt og Bæven]
parts: Name this Danish philosopher who wrote the works The Concept of Anxiety and Either/Or.

Kierkegaard contrasts the Knight of Faith with the Knight of Infinite Resignation in this work which discusses Abraham’s sacrifice of his son Isaac and asks, “Is there a teleological suspension of the ethical?” This work is named for a line from Philippians 2:12.

Kierkegaard’s three stages on life’s way are the aesthetic, the ethical, and this third stage which he considered to be the highest plane of existence. In this stage, one is ruled by “total faith in God.”
Name this poetry collection that also includes a poem about a speaker who waters his wrath “night and morning with [his] tears,” eventually murdering his foe at the end of the poem.
This British poet wrote a two-part poem about a boy who works as a chimney sweeper. He split those parts among his collections Songs of Innocence and Songs of Experience.

Blake wrote this poem that is paired with an illustration of the title plant represented as a human. This poem is included as the 12th section of Benjamin Britten’s song cycle Songs and Proverbs of William Blake.

answers: the United Kingdom and Argentina [or Great Britain and Argentina]
parts: The Falklands War was fought between these two nations.
This British prime minister was in office in 1982 during the Falklands War. This longest-serving prime minister of the 20th century was also known as the “Iron Lady.”

The surrender of the Argentinian forces occurred at this capital of the Falkland Islands. The name of this city is shared with the surname of an explorer who was famously quoted as saying “Dr. Livingstone, I presume?”
